title: At what age did you learn how to play a musical instrument? - Quora

response.answer_text: My father was a violinist and he made me a quarter size violin for my second birthday. I vaguely remember having lessons at that age, but it was too early for it to make sense, so I was let off the hook for a while. My next round of violin lessons began again when I was in elementary school. I can’t recall whether I was 6 or 7 at the time, but they continued through most of high school. I was pretty good because at music festivals I often placed first. There came a time for rebellion, though. Somewhere in my high school years, I decided to take up the bass guitar. No lessons, just figure it out. That spelled the end for the violin by the end of high school. A few years later, I was in my second band and the guitarist couldn’t listen to the radio and figure out the chords to the latest songs. I bought a cheap guitar and began to supply him with the chords. When I asked him to play chords that he didn’t know, we came to a parting of the ways. I continued to play bass with a few more bands and it was truly my instrument. Then something changed. I moved to another town for work and found a jam partner who needed a rhythm guitarist. I went back to the guitar in my 60s and, with the encouragement of my jam partner, I advanced my guitar game. It felt good once when I went to a casual musical get together with a number of people I hadn’t met before. During the course of our playing, one of them seemed to be impressed with the combination of chords I was adding to the songs. He asked me how long I had been taking lessons. I was happy to say that I hadn’t had my first lesson yet. I regret letting the violin lapse. I still know (in theory) how to play it, but I am so many years away from actually playing it that any effort would be a huge disappointment.

My parents got me an unplayable guitar and a series of group lessons when I was 12 (50+ years ago). My parents were very high I.Q.ers but didn't realize that they just set me up to fail, and it worked perfectly. As much as I wanted and practiced, the guitar never performed and frustration set in. While this problem really doesn't exist today because the Chinese became masters at making cheap but very playable guitars. (there is a lesson to be learned here.) later in life at 20 I tried agin with a guitar that was sitting around a communal apartment I was sharing. It was nylon string, the neck was set right and more playable. THat guitar sent me on a journey of playing guitar and electric guitar that morphed into electric bass then at 37 took up the upright bass for the next almost 30 years. I worked very hard learning to play it and just loved it. Played and sang in lots of bands. Then problems with my wrist, shoulder and fingers emerged and I had to stop a semi-pro career. Then about 5 years later I took up the lap steel guitar, which I'm still learning. The problem is that once your older and you've got these degenerative problems you just can't throw yourself into things like you used to plus the fire just isn't there, that's ok tho, it's all about the aging thing. My obversation about the learning thing tho is while its best to get in when your young, in your later 20's and thru your 30's there's this dedication thing that just can't be matched. In my late 60's and now 70's it's good to just play something that sounds like music.

I guess I was 11 or 12 years old and fell in love with the trumpet. I begged my Mom to get me one, but I knew she couldn’t afford it, but one day she came home with a very used trumpet that a lady from her work gave her. She played in an all-girl orchestra and was pleased to give it to my Mom. I knew how to make a sound with my lips as I had an old bugle. Shortly after, I began taking lessons with the best trumpet teacher in town and took lessons for maybe 12 years. I played in the Junior and Senior High bands and even when drafted, was surprised that I wound up in the 80th Army Band near Savannah, Georgia. While in that band, I learned how to play the string bass and took lessons which allowed me success for the next 40 years playing in trios, duos, quartets, sextets and big band. I no longer desired to play the trumpet and up until a few years ago, played bass exclusively and still have it. Today, it’s a different world as when I was a kid, you either played football or played in the school band and had the best of teachers. Today, it’s drums and guitar and forget about the other instruments……but then is gone and now is now.

I was 4 or 5 when I started learning the keyboard. Tiny toddler me was walking around a shopping centre when I heard this beautiful melody coming from somewhere. I looked into the glass window of a music store to see a lady playing the piano, oblivious that there was a young girl putting her nose so close to the glass the glass was fogging up. I was enthralled. What was this magical thing with so many buttons, and how could it make such beautiful sounds? I tugged at my mum's sleeve and asked if I could buy one. My mum laughed, and asked if I'd like lessons. I agreed immediately. I started taking organ lessons at first, and I was quite happy. I did well in class, apart from the stage fright that took over when I had to perform in front of the class. If you know me, you'll know that I'm very vertically challenged. I was the shortest kid in all of my classes. One day the teacher pulled my mom aside and told her that I was too short to reach the pedals and should probably look into playing the piano instead. I was devastated when I left the class but looking back, it was a blessing in disguise. I took up the piano and never looked back. Music is a huge part of my life, and I siezed every opportunity to learn. I took up the Yang Win (Chinese instrument) in secondary school when I was 13, then the vibraphone when I was 15, and learnt some guitar when I was 16.

Let me share my experience!! I’m 23 right now! I always had fascination for musical instruments! When I was studying in 10th standard I went to learn piano, I learned scales there! It went well!But I didn’t have a piano with me!! So I asked for a piano to my parents, and they weren’t much interested to spend 8k to something that they consider as a waste! So it was the end of my music explorations! I went for engineering, and after that I was working in an NGO Last year, while I was working in NGO, I was staying in an uncle’s home. He had a small guitar (bought for his son). It was worth for just 800 rupees! Due to some situations, I had to stay there 2–3 hours alone. I thought to try on the guitar from some guitar lessons in youtube. And I learned 2–3 chords! That felt awesome.. It happened in last year… And that changed everything… I was looking for guitar everywhere. Spent hours for finding beginner guitars! Thought and prayed for few months!! Finally I bought Yamaha F310 on May 19 2016! It is gonna be one year!! What I did was, I learned all scales and chords(maj, min and some variations) and ways to figure out chords in a song. So now, I can figure out chords in a song and strum, travis picking, and I am getting into fingerstyle… I am not an expert, but I am learning… I’m glad that I could do much better than friends who went to music school for 3–4 years and who are playing guitar for some years… That’s all! :)

Hey The timeline of my journey playing music goes something like this: Age 4 - started piano lessons Age 15 - started teaching myself drums Age 25 - began taking regular private drum lessons Age 26 - first round studying tabla. Didn't stick. Tried again at 28, also didn't stick. Will try again someday. Age 30 - started playing guitar Age 31 - began voice lessons, started playing bass Age 32 - got back into piano, teaching myself Some thoughts / conclusions: It's truly never too lateLessons can be very helpful if they help you achieve your objectives.Adolescent piano lessons gave me lasting mechanical information but only taught me to play through other people's material without understanding what I was doing or how it worked. I lacked initiative at a younger age to solve those mysteries for myself or inquire for others to help me.Now my focus is more conceptual such that I can play what I want or what I'm hearing and can explore creatively rather than being locked to notes on a page.Tabla is very challenging. :-)

I first started learning music and some simple children instruments at some kind of a Music Together class at the age of 5 in a local music school, Kosta Manojlovic, where I used to live in Belgrade/Zemun. Then when I was almost 7, I started playing violin at the same school, and then picked up the viola at the age of 16, again, same music school. I think children’ age of 5, 6, or 7 is a good age to start, as me now being a violin teacher myself and seeing little children aged 3–5 trying to start violin lessons is not always working out. The child needs to have certain abilities to play such a difficult instrument like, good focus and concentration for at least 15 minutes and also physical characteristic, as a strong bones and muscles to hold and coordinate with the instrument.

I've learned multiple instruments at different points in my life. I've always been a singer and I consider voice to be my main instrument and I think I started taking voice lessons (or at least lessons on reading music) when I was very very little. I could've even tell you an age. I learned violin in 3rd and 4th grade (so age 9 and 10 but then stopped after that) I learned piano in Middle school, probably 7th and 8th grade (13 and 14). I had known the keys on piano for years but had taken formal lessons during this time. I got a guitar and taught myself when I was 15 and I still play. I just got a ukulele for Christmas and I'm 18 and just learned to play it by teaching myself

I was 8 when I started taking recorder lessons at school. My mum (herself a pianist and guitarist) had bought me a recorder for Christmas a couple of years previously, and I figured it was about time to learn how to use it. I was 9 when I started taking flute lessons, again at school. This was a natural progression for someone who was doing pretty well with the recorder. I was lucky enough to have two years of lessons with a flute specialist (albeit in groups rather than solo) but then a succession of generic woodwind teachers - a clarinettist, a bassoonist and a saxophonist - with no specialist knowledge of the flute pretty much put paid to any dreams I had of being properly good at the instrument. I was 13 when I told my classroom music teacher I could play the piano. It was the only way to get an exemption from weeks’ worth of learning to read the treble clef and play five-note melodies with one hand, in a room full of non-musicians. Instead, I had to spend that time preparing a short recital for the class. No regrets - I certainly learned more in that time! I then went on to dep on keyboard in a church band (where I was already playing flute) and things took off from there. I was 17 when I was first given the opportunity to conduct the school band, in the first movement of Holst’s second suite in F. I was 18 when my mum bought my sister a drum kit in a last-ditch attempt to interest her in music (after giving up on the clarinet and saxophone). I used a portion of my study leave to teach myself how to play it. My sister barely touched it. I was 19 when I was playing piccolo in just two numbers of a show (Offenbach’s Orpheus in the Underworld) and they were desperately short of percussionists. I happened to have my drum sticks in my music stand case, so volunteered. That was how it all began…

When I was four or five years old my mom hired a teacher to teach me how to play the violin. It was really easy at first until my mom soon realised she was not a good teacher. So I stopped learning which was a shame. I tried the guitar but I gave up due to illness a few years ago. Now I learn the piano. My teacher is excellent and I hope to be able to do grade one piano next spring or summer. It’s easy but you have to practice and practice out of lessons and pay attention during the lesson. Ask questions and take notes. I use a notebook in the lessons to take notes. Then I study my notes whenever I’m on the go out of the flat. It helps to remind me of what I have to learn and practice. I watch videos of people playing the piano during what little free time I can get. Life is busy but there are ways to make it work for you. My child although she can’t speak yet loves to hear me play the piano in the evening after a hard day of appointments or work. Occasionally I play the piano on the weekends as well. It relaxes me. Such a useful skill to learn. I’ve been learning for eight or nine months now and I love it so much.

I started playing drums when I was 8. My sister used to play guitar and I also wanted to play an instrument. I considered playing the piano, but I thought it was way too mainstream. I thought about it for some time and then I decided I’m gonna play drums. It’s not exactly one of the most popular instruments to play, but at the same time, it’s pretty cool. It’s not everyday you see someone playing drums. And one thing I hate about playing drums is that everyone gets so surprised because I’m a girl - because it’s not common for girls to. I find that very annoying. I’ve been playing for pretty much 6 years now. I started it as a hobby, but now I really (really) like it so I decided to do my Trinity exam. I haven’t finished much though, I’m only in Grade 4. ~ Jane

When I was 11, I sat with my mum on the chair and she looked at my hands and said, 'You have very long fingers. Pianist's hands'. I said 'Can I learn to play the piano?’, and she said yes. It was as simple as that. A few weeks later, sitting in our house was an old, unrestored piano which we paid £150 for. I learnt very rapidly, and within a year I passed my grade 3. I soon outgrew my piano. We sold it to a builder who was doing work on our house at the time. He wanted it for his daughter. After a lot of saving (we've never had much money) we managed to buy a beautiful piano which I still have to this day. I was 13. It was £1600. It sounds like so much more than that… it really is a beautiful piano. The bass is phenomenal. I'll never need another piano, I just love mine so much. I took my grade 5 a year later. I then took grade 5 theory, so that I could take the higher practical grades. I was entered for my grade 8 when I was 16, but I was taking my GCSEs at the time and the stress of it all caused me to pull out of my music exam. My piano is the most important and sentimental thing I have ever received. It amazes me to think that something as simple as my mum pointing out my long fingers shaped one of the most important parts of my life.

I started about grade 3 in the US (age 9). Soprano recorder, then orchestral xylophone, then Clarinet. Nothing for more than four or five months. Violin, viola, trumpet, french horn, organ, tenor recorder, piano, each for less than a semester. It wasn’t until I was in my thirties that I came back to the piano, started putting in the hundreds then thousands of hours, did I start to have enough virtuosity to play what I thought, begin to understand how music works, and not suck so much that I could enjoy it.

Age 10 - Piano Age 12 - Violin Age 20 - Vocals Age 21 - Bass Guitar and Drums I didn’t take lessons for any of them. I hated teachers telling me what to do. I’m 22 now, I play piano for a living. And what’s funny is that I’m so good, I teach people Piano who have higher Piano qualifications. I soon will start doing the same for the drums. I’ve got guitar and saxophone on my hit list next

I was about twelve or so when I started learning to play the piano. A lot of my family members play(ed) at least one instrument. My father plays guitar, my mother the piano. My father would occasionally play with some friends on the local radio station. My grand-aunt used to play the piano and her sister would accompany her. She (my grandmother) recorded some songs in Portuguese with a musician long ago. Their brother used to play the violin and his wife would play the piano. I completed four out of the eight grades. Soon enough, I had to stop taking lessons because I had to prepare for higher education. I’m a bit rusty now, but once I play a few notes, everything sort of “comes back” and I can play like I did before.

I started with an Indian bamboo flute (the ones you can get from street hawkers) when I was in 6th standard. I got it on a whim. It is the kind that is played vertically (like a whistle or fipple or recorder flute)… I soon got bored of it and got myself a transverse flute from the same street hawkers. Fortunately I was able to produce sound without any difficulty. I merrily played some songs (mostly our national anthem and national song) but the flute was not well tuned. I gave up on it then. After a gap of many years I took up the flute again in my Engineering 3rd year and have never stopped practicing since. I kept learning on my own for about 6 years before I realised I needed a strong musical education (not just being able to play flute)..but being able to play “music” on flute. So my experience has been. Experiment with a toy instrument to find out if you have a natural affinity to it.Get a real instrument (once you are clear you have affinity to it) and experiment with itRealise you needed musical theory and musical education to actually play “music” and search for a guru.Keep practicing forever (there’s no ending or stopping point for this step!).You could follow the same steps I did but you’d be better served if you search for a guru right at the beginning. It’ll save you a lot of time and you’ll get better very quickly.

I learned some guitar from formal lessons starting around my middle school years, so around 10-13. I have not kept up very much since then, though I have played a bit every now and then since. I started self-teaching piano on and off around 13 and I have been more serious lately. So not that super-young but not that old either.

I had piano lessons around age 7 or so but only for about one year. I taught myself a bit of harmonica in high school and then around age 38 I started learning to play the ukulele and also did a deep dive into the circle of fifths and harmony and other music theory.

I started in single digits, noodling on a mandolin for the simple reason that we had a mandolin. When I was 12, an old Silvertone guitar appeared in the house, and I started noodling on that—for at least an hour a day. In my late teens, I started getting serious about music theory and got much more methodical about guitar and mandolin.

My grandmother was a piano teacher and would sit us in her lap when we were infants, hitting the keys with our hands. By four, we were taking lessons. I switched to guitar at about 8 but when I was about 11, our school got a whole set of band instruments and I went straight for the tenor saxophone. I picked up flutes when I was about 30 and my horns started getting stolen by dopers. wooden flutes are easier to replace.

I learned to play harmonium (you could say an indian keyboard) at the age of 9 and tabla at the age of 11. It's been 14 years now and I can play many instruments from harmonium, tabla, Congo, bongo, percussions to pianos and synthesizers. But still I want to learn more and I won't say that I'm an expert but yes I have improved and I'm learning.
I began playing the saxophone at age 10 and played all the way until I graduated from college. After graduating, I took a few years off and have recently started playing again, just for fun ;)

As a guitar and bass player that didn't pick up either instrument until after 40, I can assure you that the younger you are when you learn the easier it is to learn. That means the best time to learn is when you're young. If you didn't do that than the second best time to learn is now.
I started violin when I was 7 and piano at 10. But stopped piano at 11. Taught myself the guitar around 13 and the ukulele at 25. I’m still consistent with the violin. I’m happy :)
I don’t know how old I was but I started playing the trombone in 5th and I still play it in 9th grade.
I started playing the accordion at 10 years old. I will be 69 in July and I'm still playing.
I started violin at the beginning of 4th grade, when I was 9 1/2. :-)
I'm kinda like the KFC founder I got a late formal beginning. I got serious in my fifties.
I learned how to play the violin in 4th grade.
I was in 7th grade. So, around 12
